text: Anyone have any advice for making sure open source development outside of work is okay at a company? e.g. questions to ask during an interview. Its my first time looking for a permanent job and I'm not sure when contributing to Julia packages outside of work on my own time might not be allowed.

text: For sure ask, but make sure you specify that it's outside of company time. Some companies are super weird about it, some are :sunglasses:

text: I’d say it’s going to be different anywhere you work. Some companies are very encouraging and even let you contribute to open source as apart of your day-to-day work (I’ve been able to do some of this at Domo). But other places have very strict guidelines on that kind of stuff. Usually if it’s off company time and not directly related to your day job, I’d guess most companies wouldn’t mind.

Hopefully I can find a nice chill place and even able to contribute to open-source as part of day-to-day work and not be split/moonlighting. 

I'm thinking of data science type of positions but I'm not sure if open-source type work is very common with those positions since maybe it might be more focused on results and analyses and data exploration. (compared to like software dev/research software dev positions where open-source Julia work is more common).

Yeah I don't want to have to feel like I'm always constantly double checking if something is ok or not. I'm also worried that legal might just overcautiously say that its not allowed.

text: I mean, at places like Invenia and Beacon, there’s some possibility to open source work because it’s really in the best interest of the company. By open sourcing, they can collaborate w/ other companies and users to help improve code, while keeping their “secret sauce” code private obviously. But there’s a lot of more infrastructure type things that can really benefit from being open sourced. I was able to do a lot of the heavy work on HTTP.jl while working at Domo because we needed a solid webstack for the things we were doing and they were ok with open sourcing the work to get more people to help.
